title: J86-4002

sentences.text: The goal of this work is the enrichment of human-machine interactions in a natural language environment .

Because a speaker and listener can not be assured to have the same beliefs , contexts , perceptions , backgrounds , or goals , at each point in a conversation , difficulties and mistakes arise when a listener interprets a speaker 's utterance .
These mistakes can lead to various kinds of misunderstandings between speaker and listener , including reference failures or failure to understand the speaker 's intention .
Such mistakes can slow , and possibly break down , communication .
Our goal is to recognize and isolate such miscommunications and circumvent them .
This paper highlights a particular class of miscommunication -- reference problems -- by describing a case study and techniques for avoiding failures of reference .
We want to illustrate a framework less restrictive than earlier ones by allowing a speaker leeway in forming an utterance about a task and in determining the conversational vehicle to deliver it .
The paper also promotes a new view for extensional reference .

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a study on reference problems in human-machine interactions, focusing on miscommunication and proposing techniques to avoid failures of reference.

Entity-reference_problem.label: reference problems
Entity-reference_problem.description: Reference problems refer to misunderstandings in communication that arise when a listener fails to accurately interpret a speaker's utterance due to differences in beliefs, contexts, or intentions, leading to miscommunication.

Entity-a_particular_class_of_miscommunic.label: a particular class of miscommunication
Entity-a_particular_class_of_miscommunic.description: A particular class of miscommunication refers specifically to reference problems, which occur when a listener fails to correctly interpret the speaker's intended reference during communication.

Entity-this_work.label: this work
Entity-this_work.description: This work refers to a research effort aimed at enhancing human-machine interactions within natural language environments by addressing and mitigating miscommunications, particularly focusing on reference problems.

Entity-mistake.label: mistakes
Entity-mistake.description: The term 'mistakes' refers to difficulties and errors that occur during the interpretation of a speaker's utterance by a listener, which can lead to misunderstandings and miscommunication in human-machine interactions.

Entity-reference_failure.label: reference failures
Entity-reference_failure.description: Reference failures refer to misunderstandings that occur in communication when a listener misinterprets a speaker's utterance, leading to a failure in understanding the intended reference or meaning.

Entity-technique_for_avoiding_failure_of.label: techniques for avoiding failures of reference
aliases: techniques for avoiding failures of reference
Entity-technique_for_avoiding_failure_of.description: The phrase 'techniques for avoiding failures of reference' refers to specific strategies and methodologies aimed at preventing misunderstandings in communication, particularly those related to misinterpretations of references made by a speaker in a conversation.

mentions.local_name: techniques for avoiding failures of reference

Entity-the_paper.label: The paper
Entity-the_paper.description: The paper is an academic document that discusses the enrichment of human-machine interactions by addressing miscommunications, particularly reference problems, and proposes a new framework for understanding extensional reference in natural language conversations.

Entity-a_new_view_for_extensional_refere.label: a new view for extensional reference
aliases: a new view for extensional reference
Entity-a_new_view_for_extensional_refere.description: A new view for extensional reference refers to an innovative framework proposed in the paper that aims to enhance human-machine communication by allowing greater flexibility in how speakers formulate utterances and convey their intentions, particularly in addressing reference problems that can lead to miscommunication.

mentions.local_name: a new view for extensional reference

Entity-conversation.label: conversation
Entity-conversation.description: In the context of human-machine interactions, 'conversation' refers to the dynamic exchange of utterances between a speaker and a listener, where varying beliefs, contexts, and goals can lead to misunderstandings and miscommunication.

Entity-misunderstanding.label: misunderstandings
Entity-misunderstanding.description: Misunderstandings refer to the various difficulties and mistakes that arise in communication between a speaker and listener, particularly involving reference failures or misinterpretations of the speaker's intentions.

Entity-technique.label: techniques
Entity-technique.description: The term 'techniques' refers to specific methods and approaches developed in the paper to avoid failures of reference in human-machine interactions, particularly in the context of miscommunication.

Entity-various_kind_of_misunderstanding.label: various kinds of misunderstandings
Entity-various_kind_of_misunderstanding.description: Various kinds of misunderstandings refer to the different types of miscommunication that can occur between a speaker and listener during a conversation, particularly arising from differences in beliefs, contexts, perceptions, backgrounds, or goals, which may include issues like reference failures or misinterpretation of the speaker's intentions.

Entity-failure_to_understand_the_speaker.label: failure to understand the speaker's intention
aliases: failure to understand the speaker's intention
Entity-failure_to_understand_the_speaker.description: The phrase 'failure to understand the speaker's intention' refers to a specific type of miscommunication that occurs when a listener is unable to accurately interpret the intended meaning or purpose behind a speaker's utterance, leading to misunderstandings in the conversation.

mentions.local_name: failure to understand the speaker's intention

Entity-these_mistake.label: These mistakes
Entity-these_mistake.description: These mistakes refer to the difficulties and errors that arise in communication between a speaker and listener, particularly leading to misunderstandings such as reference failures or misinterpretation of the speaker's intentions.

Entity-a_case_study.label: a case study
Entity-a_case_study.description: A case study refers to a detailed examination of a specific instance of miscommunication, particularly focusing on reference problems in human-machine interactions, to illustrate techniques for avoiding such failures.

Entity-miscommunication.label: miscommunication
Entity-miscommunication.description: Miscommunication refers to a failure to communicate ideas or intentions effectively, leading to misunderstandings or errors in interaction.

Entity-work.label: work
Entity-work.description: The term 'work' refers to the research project aimed at enhancing human-machine interactions within a natural language context, focusing on identifying and mitigating miscommunications that arise from differing beliefs and contexts between speakers and listeners.

Entity-difficulty_and_mistake.label: difficulties and mistakes
Entity-difficulty_and_mistake.description: The term 'difficulties and mistakes' refers to the challenges and errors that occur in communication when a listener misinterprets a speaker's utterance due to differing beliefs, contexts, perceptions, backgrounds, or goals.

Entity-such_mistake.label: Such mistakes
Entity-such_mistake.description: Such mistakes refer to misunderstandings in communication that arise from difficulties in interpreting a speaker's utterance, particularly due to differences in beliefs, contexts, and intentions between the speaker and listener.

Entity-them.label: them
Entity-them.description: The term 'them' refers to the miscommunications that occur during human-machine interactions, particularly those arising from misunderstandings in reference and intention between speakers and listeners.

Entity-the_enrichment_of_human-machine_i.label: the enrichment of human-machine interactions
Entity-the_enrichment_of_human-machine_i.description: The enrichment of human-machine interactions refers to the enhancement of communication and understanding between humans and machines in a natural language context, aiming to reduce miscommunication and improve the effectiveness of interactions.

Entity-our_goal.label: Our goal
Entity-our_goal.description: The term 'Our goal' refers to the objective of recognizing and isolating miscommunications in human-machine interactions to circumvent misunderstandings during conversations.

Entity-communication.label: communication
Entity-communication.description: Communication refers to the process of exchanging information between a speaker and a listener, which can be hindered by misunderstandings and misinterpretations during interactions.

Entity-perception.label: perceptions
Entity-perception.description: In the context of human-machine interactions, 'perceptions' refer to the individual cognitive interpretations and understandings that speakers and listeners hold, which can differ significantly and lead to miscommunication during conversations.

Entity-difficulty.label: difficulties
Entity-difficulty.description: The term 'difficulties' refers to the challenges and problems that arise in communication due to differences in beliefs, contexts, perceptions, backgrounds, or goals between a speaker and listener, leading to misunderstandings during the interpretation of utterances.

Entity-a_framework.label: a framework
Entity-a_framework.description: A framework that provides flexibility for speakers in constructing utterances and selecting conversational methods, aimed at reducing miscommunication in human-machine interactions.

Entity-framework.label: framework
Entity-framework.description: The framework refers to a flexible conceptual structure designed to enhance human-machine interactions by allowing speakers greater freedom in formulating utterances and selecting conversational methods, thereby addressing reference problems and miscommunications.

Entity-context.label: contexts
Entity-context.description: The term 'contexts' refers to the varying beliefs, perceptions, backgrounds, and goals that influence the understanding and interpretation of utterances in human-machine interactions during conversations.

Entity-conversational_vehicle.label: conversational vehicle
Entity-conversational_vehicle.description: The term 'conversational vehicle' refers to the method or medium through which a speaker conveys an utterance in a conversation, allowing for flexibility in communication to enhance understanding and reduce miscommunication.

Entity-a_speaker_s_utterance.label: a speaker's utterance
Entity-a_speaker_s_utterance.description: A speaker's utterance refers to the verbal expression or statement made by an individual during a conversation, which may be subject to misinterpretation due to differing beliefs, contexts, and intentions between the speaker and listener.

Entity-natural_language_environment.label: natural language environment
Entity-natural_language_environment.description: A natural language environment refers to a context in which human-machine interactions occur using natural language, allowing for communication that accounts for the varying beliefs, contexts, and intentions of the participants.

Entity-goal.label: goals
Entity-goal.description: In this paper, 'goals' refers to the objectives aimed at enhancing human-machine interactions within a natural language processing framework.

Entity-speaker.label: speaker
Entity-speaker.description: The term 'speaker' refers to an individual who communicates or conveys information in a conversation, whose utterances may be subject to misinterpretation by a listener due to differing beliefs, contexts, and intentions.

Entity-a_conversation.label: a conversation
Entity-a_conversation.description: A conversation refers to the interactive exchange of spoken or written communication between a speaker and a listener, where misunderstandings may arise due to differing beliefs, contexts, perceptions, backgrounds, or goals.

Entity-a_speaker.label: a speaker
Entity-a_speaker.description: A speaker refers to an individual who produces utterances in a conversation, whose beliefs, contexts, and intentions may differ from those of the listener, potentially leading to miscommunication.

Entity-listener.label: listener
Entity-listener.description: In the context of human-machine interactions, a 'listener' refers to the participant who interprets and responds to the utterances of a speaker, while potentially facing challenges due to differing beliefs, contexts, and goals.

Entity-an_utterance.label: an utterance
Entity-an_utterance.description: An utterance refers to a spoken or written expression made by a speaker in a conversation, which can be subject to interpretation and may lead to misunderstandings due to differing beliefs, contexts, and intentions between the speaker and listener.

Entity-extensional_reference.label: extensional reference
Entity-extensional_reference.description: Extensional reference is a concept in reference theory that pertains to the relationship between linguistic expressions and the actual entities or sets of entities they denote in the world.

Entity-task.label: task
Entity-task.description: The term 'task' refers to the subject or activity that a speaker discusses in a conversation, which may involve specific objectives or actions that require clear communication to avoid misunderstandings.

Entity-belief.label: beliefs
Entity-belief.description: In the context of human-machine interactions, 'beliefs' refer to the individual cognitive frameworks or mental states that influence how speakers and listeners interpret and understand each other's utterances during a conversation.

Entity-human-machine_interaction.label: human-machine interactions
Entity-human-machine_interaction.description: Human-machine interactions refer to the various ways in which humans and machines communicate and engage with each other, encompassing both physical and digital interfaces.

Entity-background.label: backgrounds
Entity-background.description: The term 'backgrounds' refers to the diverse beliefs, contexts, perceptions, and goals that individuals possess, which can influence their understanding and interpretation during conversations.

Entity-earlier_one.label: earlier ones
Entity-earlier_one.description: The term 'earlier ones' refers to previous frameworks for human-machine interaction that imposed stricter constraints on how speakers could formulate utterances and select conversational vehicles.

Entity-utterance.label: utterance
Entity-utterance.description: An utterance is a spoken or written expression that conveys meaning in communication.

Entity-case_study.label: case study
Entity-case_study.description: A case study is a research method that involves an in-depth analysis of a specific instance or example to explore and understand complex phenomena within their real-life context.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written document that presents research findings, analyses, or arguments, typically published in an academic or professional context.

summary: The goal of this work is the enrichment of human-machine interactions in a natural language environment . Because a speaker and listener can not be assured to have the same beliefs , contexts , perceptions , backgrounds , or goals , at each point in a conversation , difficulties and mistakes arise when a listener interprets a speaker 's utterance . These mistakes can lead to various kinds of misunderstandings between speaker and listener , including reference failures or failure to understand the speaker 's intention . We call these misunderstandings miscommunication . Such mistakes can slow , and possibly break down , communication . Our goal is to recognize and isolate such miscommunications and circumvent them . This paper highlights a particular class of miscommunication -- reference problems -- by describing a case study and techniques for avoiding failures of reference . We want to illustrate a framework less restrictive than earlier ones by allowing a speaker leeway in forming an utterance about a task and in determining the conversational vehicle to deliver it . The paper also promotes a new view for extensional reference .

Predicate-is_the_enrichment_of.label: is the enrichment of
Predicate-is_the_enrichment_of.description: The predicate 'is the enrichment of' indicates a relationship where the subject contributes positively to the development, enhancement, or improvement of the object. It suggests that the subject adds value, depth, or quality to the object, thereby fostering a more comprehensive or advanced understanding or experience related to the object.

Predicate-interprets.label: interprets
Predicate-interprets.description: The predicate 'interprets' denotes the action of understanding or making sense of a communicated message or expression. It connects the subject, who is typically an individual or entity receiving the information, with the object, which is the content or message being conveyed. In this context, the subject actively engages in the cognitive process of decoding and comprehending the meaning behind the utterance made by the speaker.

Predicate-can_not_be_assured_to_have_the.label: can not be assured to have the same
Predicate-can_not_be_assured_to_have_the.description: The predicate 'can not be assured to have the same' indicates a lack of certainty or guarantee regarding the equivalence or similarity between the subject and the object. It suggests that there is doubt or an inability to confirm that the subject possesses characteristics, qualities, or states that are identical or comparable to those of the object. This predicate highlights the potential for divergence or difference in attributes, implying that while a relationship may exist, it is not one of assured sameness.

Predicate-lead_to.label: lead to
Predicate-lead_to.description: The predicate 'lead to' indicates a causal relationship where the subject is a factor or condition that results in or contributes to the occurrence of the object. It implies that the subject has a direct or indirect influence that brings about the state or situation described by the object.

Predicate-can_lead_to.label: can lead to
Predicate-can_lead_to.description: The predicate 'can lead to' indicates a potential causal relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the occurrence or existence of the subject may result in, contribute to, or facilitate the emergence of the object. It implies that while the connection is not guaranteed, there is a possibility that the subject may influence or bring about the object in certain contexts.

Predicate-are_called.label: are called
Predicate-are_called.description: The predicate 'are called' serves to establish a naming or identification relationship between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is referred to or designated by the term represented by the object, thereby linking the two in a way that conveys the meaning or classification of the subject through the terminology of the object.

Predicate-can_slow.label: can slow
Predicate-can_slow.description: The predicate 'can slow' indicates a potential or ability of the subject to reduce the speed or efficiency of the object. It suggests that the subject has the capacity to hinder or impede the normal pace or flow of the object, which is often a process, action, or interaction.

Predicate-can_possibly_break_down.label: can possibly break down
Predicate-can_possibly_break_down.description: The predicate 'can possibly break down' indicates a potential or likelihood that the subject may cause a disruption or failure in the functioning or effectiveness of the object. It suggests that under certain circumstances, the subject has the capacity to negatively impact the object, leading to a breakdown in its normal operation or interaction.

Predicate-is_to_recognize_and_isolate.label: is to recognize and isolate
Predicate-is_to_recognize_and_isolate.description: The predicate 'is to recognize and isolate' establishes a relationship where the subject aims to identify and separate a specific element or issue, represented by the object. This indicates a purposeful action or objective that involves both awareness and differentiation, suggesting that the subject seeks to understand the nature of the object by distinguishing it from other elements.

Predicate-circumvent.label: circumvent
Predicate-circumvent.description: The predicate 'circumvent' indicates an action where the subject seeks to avoid or bypass an obstacle, challenge, or restriction represented by the object. It implies a strategic or clever approach to overcoming difficulties without directly confronting them.

Predicate-highlights.label: highlights
Predicate-highlights.description: The predicate 'highlights' indicates that the subject brings attention to, emphasizes, or makes prominent a specific aspect, feature, or element represented by the object. It suggests a focus on the importance or relevance of the object in relation to the subject, often aiming to inform or draw the audience's awareness to that particular point.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' indicates a relationship where the subject provides an account, explanation, or representation of the object. It signifies that the subject conveys information or details about the object, allowing for a clearer understanding or insight into the nature, characteristics, or context of the object.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' establishes a relationship where the subject encompasses or contains the object as a part or component. It indicates that the object is a subset or an element that falls within the broader category or context defined by the subject.

Predicate-determines.label: determines
Predicate-determines.description: The predicate 'determines' indicates a relationship in which the subject exerts influence or control over the characteristics, nature, or outcome of the object. In this context, the subject actively shapes or defines the object, establishing a causal or defining link between them.

Predicate-is_less_restrictive_than.label: is less restrictive than
Predicate-is_less_restrictive_than.description: The predicate 'is less restrictive than' establishes a comparative relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject imposes fewer limitations, constraints, or requirements compared to the object. This suggests a degree of flexibility or openness in the subject relative to the object, which is characterized by greater restrictions.

Predicate-is_about.label: is about
Predicate-is_about.description: The predicate 'is about' establishes a relationship where the subject provides information, context, or relevance concerning the object. It indicates that the subject's content, theme, or focus pertains to the object, thereby linking the two in a way that highlights the subject's connection or relevance to the object.

Predicate-has_leeway_in_forming.label: has leeway in forming
Predicate-has_leeway_in_forming.description: The predicate 'has leeway in forming' indicates that the subject possesses a degree of flexibility or freedom in the process of creating or constructing the object. This suggests that the subject can make choices or variations in how the object is expressed or articulated, allowing for creativity, adaptation, or personalization in the formation of the object.

Predicate-has_leeway_in_determining.label: has leeway in determining
Predicate-has_leeway_in_determining.description: The predicate 'has leeway in determining' indicates that the subject possesses the flexibility or freedom to make choices or decisions regarding the characteristics, nature, or selection of the object. It suggests that the subject is not strictly bound by rules or limitations and can exercise personal judgment or discretion in how the object is defined or utilized.

Predicate-promotes.label: promotes
Predicate-promotes.description: The predicate 'promotes' indicates that the subject actively supports, advocates for, or encourages the acceptance or development of the object. It suggests a positive influence or endorsement of the object, which often involves introducing new ideas, concepts, or practices to a wider audience.

Predicate-addresses.label: addresses
Predicate-addresses.description: The predicate 'addresses' indicates that the subject engages with, discusses, or responds to the object, often highlighting a specific issue, topic, or area of concern. It implies a connection where the subject provides insights, solutions, or commentary relevant to the object.

Predicate-refers_to.label: refers to
Predicate-refers_to.description: The predicate 'refers to' establishes a relationship where the subject is identified or associated with the object, indicating that the subject is a representation, example, or specific instance of the concept or category denoted by the object. This connection implies that the subject provides a way to understand, categorize, or discuss the object in a meaningful context.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or category within the wider scope defined by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a larger set of concepts or categories that includes the subject, thereby illustrating a classification or categorization where the subject is a subset of the broader term.
